Winter in San Francisco cold, foggy.  Cop cars everywhere The lights play through the thick fog.  Two Homicide dete get out of the car, walk into the house. NICK CURRAN is 42.  Trim, good-looking, a nice suit; a fa urban, edged, shadowed.  GUS MORAN is 64.  Crew-cut, silv beard, a suit rumpled and shiny, a hat out of the 50'sa f worn and ruined the face of a backwoods philosopher.
There's money here -- deco, clean, hip -- That looks like Picasso on the wall.  They check it out.
Who was this fuckin' guy?
Rock and roll, Gus.  Johnny Boz.
I never heard of him.
(grins) Before your time, pop. (a beat) Mid-sixties.  Five or six hits. He's got a club down in the Fillmore  now.
Not now he don't.
Past the uniformed guys... nods... waves... past the fore men... past the coroner's investigators... they get to th bedroom.

They walk in, stare -- it's messy. It's like a convention in here.  LT. PHIL WALKER, in his silver-haired, the Homicide guys; JIM HARRIGAN, late 40's puffy, affable;  SAM ANDREWS, 30's, black.  A CORONER'S M working the bed.
(to Nick and Gus) You guys know Captain Talcott?
They nod.
What's the Chief's office doin'  here.
Observing.
(to the Coroner's  Guy) What do you think, Doc?
The skin blanches when I press it -- this kind of color is about right  for six or eight hours.
Nobody say anything.  The maid  came in an hour ago and found him. She's not a live-in.
Maybe the maid did it.
She's 54 years old and weighs 240  pounds.
(deadpan) There are no bruises on his body.
(grins) It ain't the maid.
He left the club with his girlfriend  about midnight.  That's the last  time anybody saw him.
(looks at body) What was it?
Ice pick.  Left on the coffee table  in the living room.  Thin steel  handle.  Forensics took it downtown.
There's come all over the sheets -- he got off before he got offed.
(deadpan) That rules the maid out for sure.
This is sensitive.  Mr. Boz was a  major contributor to the mayor's  campaign.  He was Chairman of the  Board of the Palace of Fine Arts --
(to Nick) I thought you said he was a rock  and roll star.
He was a retired rock and roll  star.
A civic-minded, very respectable  rock and roll star.
What's that over there?
We see the white powder laid out in lines on the small mi on the side table.
(deadpan) It looks like some civic-minded,  very respectable cocaine to me,  Gus.
(evenly, to Nick) Listen to me, Curran.  I'm going  to get a lot of heat on this.  I  don't want any... mistakes.
Nick and Talcott look at each other a beat, then --
Who's the girlfriend?
Lt. Walker looks at the notepad in his hand.
Catherine Tramell, 162 Divisadero.
Nick writes it down.  He and Gus turn, leave.  Captain Ta watches them.  He looks disturbed.
As they head out --
Talcott doesn't usually show up at  the office 'till after his 18 holes.   What are they nervous about?
They're executives.  They're nervous  about everything.
Nick!
He stops, turns, sees Walker behind them.  Walker comes u them.
(to Nick) Keep your three o'clock.
Do you want me to work the case,  Phil, or do you want me to --
I said keep it.
It is more a mansion than a house.  They ring the bell. Hispanic MAID answers.  They flash their badges.
I'm Detective Curran, this is  Detective Moran.  We're with the  San Francisco Police Department.
We'd like to speak to Ms. Catherine Tramell.
(after a beat, an  accent) Just moment.  Come in.
She leads them into a lavish, beautifully done living roo that offers a sweeping view of the Bay.
Sit, please.  Just moment.
They look around, impressed.  There is a Picasso on the w here, too.
Ain't that cute?  They got his and  her Pig-assos, son.
(smiles) I didn't know you knew who Picasso  was, Gus.
(grins) I'm a smart sonofabitch.  I just  hide it.
Nick smiles -- and at that moment a beautiful BLONDE walk into the room.  She looks like she has been asleep.  She her early 20's.  She wears a very sheer robe.
We're sorry to disturb you, we'd  like to ask you some --
Are you vice?
(after a beat) Homicide.
What do you want?
When was the last time you saw  John Boz?
Is he dead?
(after a beat) Why do you think he's dead?
You wouldn't be here otherwise,  would you?
Were you with him last night?
You're looking for Catherine, not  me.
Who are you?
I'm Roxy. (a beat) I'm her -- friend.
She looks at them a beat.
She's out at the beach house at  Stinson.  Seadrift.  1402.
Thanks.
They start to head out.
You're wasting your time. Catherine  didn't kill him.
A beat, they look at her, and go...

Foggy.  Cold.  It is an expensive spit of land on the oce Multi-million dollar "beach houses" with gardens and swim pools.  There are two Ferraris in the driveway -- one bla one white. They get out of the car in front of the house.  They see woman in back of the house, sitting on a deck chair, star at the sea, a blanket around her.  As they get to her --
Ms. Tramell?

She takes a long look a Nick, then looks away. CATHERINE TRAMELL is 30 years old.  She has long blonde h and a refined, classically beautiful face.  She is not kn gorgeous like Roxy; there is a smoky kind of sensuousness her.
I'm De...
(evenly) I know who you are.
She doesn't look at them.  She looks at the water.
How did he die?
He was murdered.
Really.  Maybe that's why you're  from Homicide.  How?
Nick glances at Gus.
With an ice pick.
She closes her eyes a beat and then, still staring out, w a thin smile.  They see it, too, and glance at each other
How long were you dating him?
I wasn't dating him.  I was fucking  him.
They glance at each other again.
What are you -- a pro?
Catherine looks at him -- that thin smile again.
No.  I'm an amateur.
She looks away.
How long were you having sex with  him?
About a year and a half.
Were you with him last night?
Yes.
Did you leave the club with him?
Yes.
Did you go home with him?
No.  We had a drink at the club. We left together.  I came here.   He went home.
Was there anyone with you last  night?
(looks at Nick) No.  I wasn't in the mood to have  sex with anyone last night.
They look at her a beat.
Let me ask you something, Ms. Tramell?  Are you sorry he's dead?
Catherine looks at him.
Yes.  I liked fucking him.
They stare at her.  She looks out at the water.
I don't really feel like talking  anymore.
Listen, lady, we can do this  downtown if you --
Read me my rights and arrest me  and I'll go downtown.
She doesn't even look at them.
(quietly) Otherwise, get the fuck out of  here.  Please.
A long beat as they look at her.
The door says Dr. Elizabeth Gardner, Counseling.  Nick op the door, peeks in.  The receptionist is not there.  A cl says 3.
He walks in -- sees the inner door open, walks in.
I'm sorry, Beth.  I -- I got hung  up in Stinson.
DR. ELIZABETH GARDNER, the police psychologist, is a very looking, dark-haired woman.  She is 30.
(smiles) How are you, Nick?
I'm fine.  Come on, Beth!  You  know I'm fine!  How the hell long  do I have to keep doing this?
As long as Internal Affairs wants  you to, I suppose.  Sit down, Nick.
It's bullshit.  You know it is.
(smiles) I know it is -- but sit down anyway  so we can get it over with, okay?
He sits down.
So -- how are things?
(after a beat) Things are fine.  I told you. They're fine.
She watches him closely.
(after a beat) How is your -- personal life?
My sex life is fine. (a beat) My sex life is pretty shitty  actually since I stopped seeing  you -- maybe I should think about  my Electrolux again.
That embarrassed her; she looks away from him.
(after a beat) Sorry.
She shrugs.  A beat.
How about the booze?
It's been three months.
(after a long beat) How about the coke?
No.
No?
(hard) No!  I'm working my tail off.  I'm  off the sauce, I'm not even smoking  anymore.
She smiles.
How's not smoking?
It's fucked -- now will you please  tell I.A. that I'm just you average  healthy totally fucked-up cop and  let me get out of here?
(after a beat; smiles) Yes.
Thank you.
And he starts heading out.
(behind him) I still miss you, Nick.
He doesn't even turn, pretends he didn't hear.
He walks in.  Gus Moran gets up from his desk as soon as sees him.
Talcott's in there.  They're  waiting.
They start heading for Lt. Walker's office.
How'd it go, son?
She misses me.
(grins) Hallelujah.
He and Gus sit there with Lt. Walker, Harrigan, Andrews a Captain Talcott.

Sixteen stab wounds to the chest  and neck.  No usable prints, no  forcible entry, nothing missing. No prints on the ice pick, either -- it's available at any Safeway. The scarf is Hermes, expensive -- they sell about 20,000 a year  worldwide.

The powder was cocaine, high- quality, high-content.  He inhaled  it; there were minute quantities  on his lips and penis.  Mr. Boz  leaves five million dollars, no  insurance, no direct survivors.   He liked his coke, he liked his  girls, and he liked rock and roll.
He liked the mayor, too, right?
Talcott gives him a look.
What about his girlfriend?
Is she relevant here?  I didn't  know she was a suspect.
She's a suspect.
On what basis?

(looks a notes) Catherine Tramell.  Age 30.  No  priors, no convictions.  Double  major, magnum cum laude, Berkeley,  1980.  Literature and Psychology. Daughter, sole survivor -- Marvin  and Elaine Tramell, killed in a  boating accident, 1978, Catherine  Tramell sole heir.  Estimated assets  $110 million.
It hangs there.
Are you kidding me?
(continues) Formerly engaged to Roberto Vasquez,  deceased --
Bobby Vasquez?
Bobby Vasquez, former middleweight  contender, killed in the ring  Atlantic City, 1984.
(smiles) I love it.  She's got a hundred  million bucks.  She fucks fighters  and rock and roll stars.  And she's  got a degree in screwing with  peoples' heads.
You forgot her degree in literature.   She's a writer.  She published a  novel last year under a pen name.   Do you want to know what it's about?
They just stare at him.
It's about a retired rock and roll  star who is murdered by his  girlfriend.
It hangs there a long beat.

His apartment is very bare -- very few things -- with wid open spaces.  There is a lot of chrome. He sits on the couch, reading a book.  It is a paperback. We see the title -- Love Hurts, by Catherine Adams.  He p the book down a beat, then picks the phone up, dials.
Page 67, pop.  Do you know how she  does the boyfriend?  With an  icepick, in bed, his hands tied  with a white silk scarf.
Nick, Gus, Lt. Walker, Harrigan, Andrews, Captain Talcott and Beth Gardner.  With them is an older, white-haired ma DR. ANDREW LAMOTT.  There are copies of "Love Hurts" arou the table.
Dr. Gardner?

I've asked Dr. Lamott to consult  with us.  This isn't really my  turf.  Dr. Lamott teaches the psycho- pathology of psychopathic behavior  at Stanford and is also a member  of the Justice Department's  Psychological Profile team.  Dr.   Lamott?

There are two possibilities.  One.   The person who wrote this book is  your murderer and acted out the  killing described in ritualistic,  literal detail.  Two.  Someone who  wants to do the person who wrote  this book harm read the book and  enacted the killing described to  incriminate the writer.
(after a long beat) What if the writer did it?  What  are we dealing with?

You're dealing with a devious,  diabolical mind.  This book must  have been written at least six  months, maybe years before it was  published.  That means the writer  planned the crime, at least in the  subconscious, back then.  The fact  that the writer carried it out  indicates psychopathic obsessive  behavior in terms not only of the  killing itself but in terms of  applied advance defense mechanism.
A long beat.
Most times I can't tell shit from  shinola, Doc.  What was all that  you just said?
Some grins, titters.
She anticipates the book to be her  best alibi.
Correct.
She's going to say Do you think  I'd be dumb enough to kill anyone  in the exact way I've described in  my book?  I wouldn't do that because  I'd know I'd be a suspect.
A long beat -- as they think about it.
What if it's not the writer?  What  if it's someone who read the book?

You're dealing then with someone  so obsessed that he or she is  willing to kill an irrelevant and  innocent victim to place the blame  on the person who wrote this book.   We are talking about deep-seated,  obsessional hatred; an utter lack  of sense of proportion or  perspective.
We've got a top-of-the-line, once- in-a-lifetime loony-tune either  way you cut it -- that's what you're  saying, right, Doc?
You're dealing with someone very  dangerous and very ill.
PROSECUTOR JOHN CORRIGAN, a big man in his 50's, with Cap Talcott, Lt. Walker, Nick, and Gus. Corrigan is reading a file.  He gets up, yawns, goes to h window, looks out.

Come on, you know there's no case  here.  There's no physical evidence --  okay, she doesn't have an alibi  but there's no motive.  Her defense  would just beat us to death with  the copycat thing.  Anybody who  read the book could have done it.
A long beat; no one says anything.
So what do we do -- nothing?
(after a beat) We bring her in for questioning.
She's got enough money to burn  this whole department down.
She was the last person seen with  the guy -- I'll take the  responsibility.
It's yours.
It won't do any good.  She'll come  in with Lee Bailey and Mel Belli  trailing behind her on a solid  gold chain from Tiffanys.
Yes she will.
(after a beat) No she won't.
They look at him.
(smiles) I don't think she's going to hide  behind anybody.  I don't think  she's going to hide at all.
(after a beat) I think you're as crazy as she  probably is, Curran.
Nicks says nothing.
You know what they say: It takes  one to know one.
Nick looks a Gus, grins.
They walk from the car to the door of the big beach house They ring the bell.  They hear typing inside.  The typing She comes to the door in jeans and a tight-fitting sweats
Ms. Tramell, we'd like you to come  downtown and answer some questions  for us.
Are you arresting me?
If that's the way you want to play  it.
They look at each other a beat.
(smiles) Can I change into something more  appropriate?  It'll just take a  minute.
He nods.
Come in.

It is beautifully done in a Santa Fe motif.  She goes to bedroom of the living room. Nick sits down on a couch facing the bedroom she's walked Gus sits across from him, his back to the bedroom. There is a coffee table between them.  She leaves the bed door halfway open. An old newspaper is on the coffee table.  Nick reaches fo The headline says VICE COP CLEARED IN TOURIST SHOOTINGS. headline underneath says GRAND JURY SAYS SHOOTINGS ACCIDE There is a photograph of Nick. He stares at the paper.
How long will this take?
Nick puts the paper down on the coffee table.  He is lost his thoughts.  Gus picks the paper up.
(looks up) I don't know.

Nick, facing the half open bedroom door, sees a mirror ne the wall of the bedroom.  The mirror reflects her in the corner of the bedroom.  She is taking her clothes off.  H stares.  She strips down.  He sees her back. She has a be body.  Naked, she puts a dress on.  She doesn't put any  underwear on.
Do you always keep old newspapers  around?
Only when they make interesting  reading.
And she is suddenly out of the bedroom.  She stands there smiles.  They look at each other a long beat.
(finally) I'm ready.
They get up, head out.
You have the right to an attorney.
Why would I need an attorney?
They sit in the front; she is in the back.  The car goes the winding, two-lane Mt. Tamalpais road. The fog is heavy.  It's starting to rain.  We see the bea far below.
Do you have a cigarette?
I don't smoke.
Yes, you do.
I quit.
She smiles, looks at him.  A beat, and he turns away.  An beat, and she lights a cigarette up.
I thought you were out of  cigarettes.
I found some in my purse; would  you like one?
He turns back to her.
I told you -- I quit.
It won't last.
A beat, as she looks at him, and then he turns away.
You workin' on another book?
Yes I am.
It must really be somehtin' --makin'  stuff up all the time.
He watches her in the rearview mirror.
It teaches you to lie.
How's that?
You make it up, but it has to be  believable.  They call it suspension  of disbelief.
I like that.  "Suspension of  Disbelief."
He smiles at her in the mirror.
What's your new book about?
A detective.  He falls for the  wrong woman.
He turns back to her.
What happens to him?
She looks right into his eye.
She kills him.
A beat, as they look at each other, and then he turns awa from her.  Gus watcher her in the rearview mirror.

It is large, fluorescent-lighted, antiseptic. She walks in with Nick and Gus.  In the room are prosecut John Corrigan, Lt. Walker, Captain Talcott, Harrigan, and Andrews.  There is a police stenographer a plain young wo in her 20's. As soon as she comes in --
I'm John Corrigan.  I'm an assistant  district attorney, Ms.  Tramell.   Can we get you anything?  Would  you like some coffee?
No thank you.
Are your attorneys --
(hiding a smile) Ms. Tramell waived her right to an  attorney.
Corrigan and Talcott glance at Nick.  She sees the look.
(smiles) Did I miss something?
I told them you wouldn't want an  attorney present.
Why have you waived your right to  an attorney, Ms. Tramell?
(to Nick) Why did you think I wouldn't want  one?
I told them you wouldn't want to  hide.
I have nothing to hide.

The two of them keep their eyes on each other. She sits down.  They sit around her.  Nick sits directly from her.  She lights up a cigarette.  They watch her.   She is poised, cool, in complete command of herself.
There is no smoking in this  building, Ms. Tramell.
What are you going to do?  Charge  me with smoking?
Ever so casually, she blows her smoke across at Nick.
Would you tell us the nature of  your relationship with Mr. Boz?
I had sex with him for about a  year and a half.  I liked having  sex with him.
She has control of the room; she looks from one man to th other as she speaks.
He wasn't afraid of experimenting.   I like men like that.  I like men  who give me pleasure.  He gave me  a lot of pleasure.
A beat, as they watch her.  She is so matter-of-fact.
Did you ever engage in sado- masochistic activity with him?
(smiles) Exactly what do you have in mind,  Mr. Corrigan.
(after a beat, little  flustered) Did you ever tie him up?
No.
You never tied him up.
No. Johnny liked to use his hands  too much.  I like hands and fingers.
They stare at her.
You describe a white silk scarf in  your book.
I've always had a fondness for  white silk scarves. (she smiles) I have a very vivid imagination.
But you said you liked men to use  their hands.
No.  I said I liked Johnny to use  his hands. (she smiles) I don't give any rules, Nick.  I  go with the flow.
They have their eyes on each other.
Did you kill Mr. Boz, Ms. Tramell?
I'd have to be pretty stupid to  write a book about a killing and  then kill him the way I described  in my book. I'd be announcing myself  as the killer.  I'm not stupid.
She smiles.
We know you're not stupid, Ms. Tramell.
Maybe that's what you're counting  on to get you off the hook.
Writing a book about it gives you  an alibi for not killing him.
Yes it does, doesn't it?
She holds his eyes a second, then --
The answer is no.  I didn't kill  him.
Do you use drugs, Ms. Tramell?
Sometimes.
Did you ever do drugs with Mr.  Boz?
Sure.
What kind of drugs?
Cocaine.
She looks directly at Nick.
Have you ever fucked on cocaine? (she smiles) It's nice.
He watches her.
You like playing games, don't you?
(smiles) I've got a degree in psych.  It  goes with the turf.  Games are  fun.
They are holding each other's eyes.
How about boxing?  That's a game. Was that fun for you?
They don't take their eyes off each other for a second.
I think that's irrelevant to this  inquiry.
(to Nick) Yes it was.  Bobby died.
How did you feel when he died?
I loved him.  I hurt.
Their eyes are still on each other.
How did you feel when I told you  Johnny Boz had died -- that day at  the beach.
I felt somebody had read my book  and was playing a game.
But you didn't hurt --
No.
Because you didn't love him --
That's right.
Their eyes are digging into each other.
Even though you were fucking him.
(after a beat) You still get the pleasure.  Didn't  you ever fuck anybody else while  you were married, Nick?
A beat; he stares at her, expressionless.
How did you know he was married?
(watching Nick) Maybe I was guessing.  What  difference does it make?
She lights a cigarette.  He stares at her.
Would you like a cigarette, Nick?
He just stares at her, expressionless.
Do you two know each other?
No.
No.
How did you meet Mr. Boz?
I wanted to write a book about the  murder of a retired rock star.  I  went down to his club and picked  him up.  Then I had sex with him.
You didn't feel anything for him. You just had sex with him for your  book.
She looks at Nick.
In the beginning.  Then I got to  like what he did for me.
That's pretty cold, ain't it, lady?
I'm a writer,  I use people for  what I write.  You write what you  know.  Let the world beware.
She and Nick have their eyes on each other, then --
(to Corrigan, smiles) Would you like me to take a lie  detector test?

We see her in a glass-enclosed cubicle with a polygraph  EXAMINER.  Nick stands outside watching her with Gus and Walker.  Her back is to them.  The Examiner shuts the mac down, gathers rolls of papers, and comes out of the cubic
No blips, no blood pressure  variations, no pulse variance.   Either she's telling the truth or  I've never met anyone like her.
A long beat, then --
Well, I guess that's it.
A long beat, Nick watches her as she sits inside.
How does somebody beat this machine?

Ninety-nine point nine percent of  the cases, they don't.  You'd have  to be able to mask the truth from  your own central nervous system,  your circulatory system, your  adrenal glands.  In my opinion,  this woman is telling the truth.
The Examiner walks away.  They stand there. Catherine sta at the door of the cubicle behind them --
Can I go now?
(after a beat) Yes.  Thanks for coming in, Ms. Tramell.  I'm sorry to inconvenience  you.
She says nothing, has a thin smile.
Can I ask one of you for a ride?
They look at her a beat.
Sure.
(smiles) Thanks.
And he and Catherine walk away.  Gus and Walker watch the
It is an old, mint-condition silver Porsche.  It is pouri rain; the wind is blowing a San Francisco winter storm. is said a long beat as he drives.  She yawns.  Stretches. looks at her.
(smiles) I'm tired.
It's got to be tiring to beat that  machine.
She looks at him and looks away.  A beat.
If I were guilty, and if I wanted  to beat that machine, it wouldn't  be tiring.  It wouldn't be tiring  at all.
Why not?
Because I'm a professional liar.   I spend most of my waking hours  dwelling on my lies. (a beat) For my writing.
He looks at her.
(smiles) I love the rain, don't you?
He says nothing, doesn't look at her.
You took a polygraph after you  shot those two people, didn't you?
He looks at her now.
I passed.
You see?  We're both innocent,  Nick.
He pulls up in front of her house on Divisadero, stops. sees the white Ferrari in the driveway.
How do you know all this stuff  about me?
You know all about me.
I don't know anything that isn't  police business.
(after a beat) You know I don't like to wear any  underwear, don't you, Nick?
They look at each other a beat.
(smiles) Thanks for the ride.
And she's out of the car.  He watches her as she hurries the rain -- his eyes on her until the moment she opens th door and is inside.
It is a police bar, San Francisco style.  Ferns  Joe Mont and Will Clark posters.  The jukebox has a lot of Tony Be He walks in.  He sees Lt. Walker at a back booth with Gus goes to them, sits down.
What is all this "Nick" stuff -- Nick would you like a cigarette. Nick can you give me a ride.
She didn't ask me for the ride. She asked anybody.
And you volunteered.
A BARTENDER stays behind the bar, but yells to him.
Perrier, Nick?
Double Black Jack rocks, Harry.
(with concern) What you doin', son?
It's my first drink in three months.   That okay with you, pop? (to Lt. Walker) She doesn't know me.  I never saw  her before Gus and I talked to  her.
Here you go, Nick.
He gets up, gets his drink --
Thanks, Harry.
He sits back down.  He takes a big slug.  They watch him.
You sure?
I'm sure.
He takes another big slug.
Now what?
What now what? Now nothing.  She  passed the polygraph.  That's it.
She knew she could beat it.  That's  why she asked to take it.
How the fuck do you know?  What is  it with you and this broad anyway?

Come on, Phil.  You're not gonna  let this slide.  What about her  parents?  What about what else  she's published?  At least we should  get the stuff to see if we find  anything else that's an amazing  real-life coincidence.
Her parents died in an accident.   I don't care what else she's  written.  What are you -- a book  critic?
How did they die?  Was there an  investigation?
How you're saying she killed her  parents?  Did she kill Bobby  Vasquez, too?
Not unless she got up in the ring  and turned into one mean  sonofabitch.
Maybe she did, Gus.  Maybe she  grew herself an Afro and learned a  left hook and put shoe polish on  her face.  Let's polygraph her  again and ask her about it.
(casually) Fuck you, Phil.
Fuck you, too Nick.
A beat, then --
(calls to the  Bartender) Can you get me another double Black  Jack, Harry.
Gus looks at him with concern.  A man in his 50's -- LT. NILSEN  is suddenly there.  He is overweight, florid.
(to Nick) Hey, shooter -- You back on the  Black Jack, Shooter?
He grins.  Nick doesn't look at him.
We're discussing a case, Marty.
I know that.  I had no doubt of  that.
Here you go, Nick.
Nilsen takes the drink, hands it to Nick.
(grins) Double, huh, Shooter?
Nick turns to him.  He's sitting in the booth; Nilsen is  standing there.  Nick looks like he's barely restraining  himself.
I'm off-duty, Nilsen.  You hear  me?  I'm off-duty discussing a  case.  Internal Affairs shouldn't  have any trouble with that.  Maybe  I should put in for overtime.
(grins) You do that, Shooter.  Why don't  you send it to me?  I'll give it  special attention.
A beat, and then Nick gets up, faces him.
I'm gonna tell you once more, Nilsen --
Lt. Walker and Gus get up and hold Nick back. Beth Gardner, the police psychologist, is suddenly there.
What's the problem?
(grins) No problem, Doctor.  Here comes  the Doctor just in time to save  her patient.  Take care, Shooter.
And he walks away.  Nick still looks like he wants to go him.  Beth pulls him away from the booth.
You okay?
(after a beat) Yeah.
(smiles) You don't look so okay.
Nick looks at her a beat.
(smiles) What are you doing here?
(smiles) Baby-sitting. (she shrugs) Rookie cop.
(smiles) What else is new?
A beat.  He looks at her again.
You want to get out of here?
She looks at him a beat.
(smiles) Yes.
At the booth, Gus and Lt. Walker watch the two of them le
Maybe it's for old-time's sake.
(watches them go  out) Sometimes I think he started banging  her just to get himself off the  hook with Internal Affairs.
(after a beat, smiles) He ain't that way.  He's got heart.
(smiles) Yeah.  I know.
He is kissing her -- hard, rough.  He forces her against wall.
Don't -- please, Nick --
We hear her dress RIP.  He kisses her harder -- we hear h panties RIP.  He gets the dress off, pushes his hands und her bra --
Please don't -- don't --
He puts his mouth to her shoulder, bites it -- as they mo down to the floor.

It is dark.  The are still partially dressed.  They are o floor.  He lies on his back, staring at the ceiling. She lies next to him -- the torn dress wound around her. There is a bite mark on her shoulder.  A long beat, silen then --
What was she like?
Who?
Catherine Tramell.
(after a beat) She said what you said she'd say.
She sits up, looks away.  He looks at her, puts his finge the bite mark idly, gently.  A beat, and he kisses her sh gently, then lies back down.
I met her at Berkeley.
He looks at her.
We were in some of the same classes.
(after a beat) Why didn't you tell me?
She looks at him.
I'm telling you.
They look at each other a long beat.
(with difficulty) You've never been... like that...   before.
He says nothing, looks away from her.
Why?
He doesn't look at her a long beat, says nothing.
You're the shrink.
She keeps looking at him.  He won't look at her.
You weren't making love to me.
A beat; he looks at her.
Who was I making love to?
She looks at him a long beat.
You weren't making love.
They look at each other, a long beat, then away.  He lies down.  Beth doesn't look at him, keeps sitting up.
(finally) I need a cigarette.
(after a beat) I thought you quit.
He says nothing.
Top drawer in the foyer. (a beat) Get it on your way out.
He looks at her; she won't look at him.
He walks in.  He looks hung-over.  He sees Gus with Harri and Andrews and Lt. Walker in Lt. Walker's glass-enclosed at the end of this big room. They look at him when they see him.
You look like dogshit.
(grins) He looks a little shrunk, that's  all.
(after a beat) We got a call from Berkeley P.D. There was a killing.  A professor. Icepick.  In his bed.  Multiple  stab wounds.  1977.
(a thin smile) She was there, wasn't she?
University records say she was  there.
He and Nick look at each other a long beat, then --

(suddenly) Gus -- go over to Berkeley. Harrigan -- find out what else  she's published.  Andrews -- get  the files on her parents' accident. Carbon Beth on everything.  I want  some psychological input on this  Andrews and Harrigan go; Nick is  left there with Gus.
What about me?
You're already gettin' psychological  input, son.
(to Nick) Go stick your head in a tub of ice  water. (a beat; then  seriously) See where she leads.

The black Ferrari is in the driveway.  He sits in an unma police car on a hillside above the house, watching.  It i bleak, leaden gray day. Catherine comes out of the house.  She is dressed casuall She gets into the Ferrari.

He stays behind her at a safe distance on the winding pan highway -- a two-lane mountain road which leads from Stin Beach into Marin County. She suddenly starts speeding up on this dangerous road, c in and out, passing cars very fast. He has to start cutting around cars to keep up.  This wom really drives. He cuts out and can barely pass a car without hitting a G Lines Tour Bus head-on.  Close call: sheer drops on eithe side. He looks frazzled.

He is behind her at a distance on a hilly Mill Valley roa little streets, terraced hillsides, sharp turns. He goes slowly, looks around, thinks he's lost her.  And he sees the black Ferrari parked in front of a house obsc by hedges. He parks the car a distance behind the Ferrari, sits ther long beat.  He gets out, goes carefully up to the hedges, A small, nondescript house.  He watches.  He can't see an inside the house. A beat, he reaches over to the mailbox and opens it.  He an envelope out, looks at the name Hazel Dobkins.

He watches as she comes out of the house.  A frail old wo in her 70's is with her.  She hugs the old woman, gets in the Ferrari, STARTS it up. He waits a beat and then STARTS after her.  He stays behi her at a distance -- she is going slowly.  And then she s GUNS it, cuts her lights -- her wheels SCREECH. He GUNS his car after her.  He makes a turn.  She is gone There is a fork in the road.  He turns one way, goes a fe hundred feet. Nothing.  Blackness.  He stops.
(quietly) Shit.

He pulls his car up to her house at Stinson Beach.  The b Ferrari is in the driveway. A light goes on in an upstairs bedroom.  The curtain is d He sees the outline of her body now. She starts to take her clothes off -- there in the window behind the curtain.  He watches her body as she does an a languorous strip.  His eyes are intense... ravishing.

He is alone, nobody else in the big room. He sits in front of a computer.  We see the screen.  He h punched in HAZEL DOBKINS, WF, 145 ALBION RD., MILL VALLEY. He is waiting for a response.  We see it come on screen NOTHING CURRENT. A long beat, as he stares at the screen, and then we see words RELEASED, SAN QUENTIN, JULY 7, 1965. We see him type in the words PRIOR ARREST RECORD. A long beat, and then it comes up
He stares at the screen a long beat.
(behind him) Ain't you go nothin' better to do  than to come in here and jack off  the damn machine?
(after a beat; lost  in his thoughts) What are you doing here, Pop?
(grins) I came in here to jack off the  damn machine. (a beat) One dead psychology professor. Noah Goldstein.  Dr. Noah Goldstein.   And guess what?  He was her  counselor.
Nick looks at him a beat.
Was she ever suspect?
No, sir.  They never even got a  statement from her.
Nick sits back a long beat, his eyes off somewhere.
(slowly) Do you remember a case -- 1956 -- Hazel Dobkins?

(grins) Hell yes!  Couldn't get it outta  my head for years.  Still can't.   Nice little kids -- nice husband,  wasn't porkin' around -- no  financial problems.  One day --  outta the clear blue sky -- she  does 'em.  All of 'em.  Used a  knife. He got for a wedding present.   Didn't even deny it.  Sweet as  honey.  Said she didn't know why  she done it.
Nick just stares at him.

He pulls up to the house, gets out of his unmarked police He stands there a beat, thinking.  He walks down to the b entrance of the house.  He hears a Rolling Stones SONG pl inside.  He stands there.  The door suddenly opens.  Cath stands there, smiles.  She wears very tight-fitting spand leotards.
Hi.
He looks at her a beat, then --
Am I... disturbing you?
No.  Come in.
They have their eyes on each other.  A beat, and she turn go in.

She goes in ahead of him -- he follows her inside.  He wa her body.  His movements are tentative, off-balance.  She the Stones DOWN. On a table by the window, he sees a word processor.  Spre around it are newspaper clippings.  They are all about hi We see the headline on one KILLER COP TO FACE POLICE REVI She sees him glancing at the clips.
I'm using you for my detective.   In my book.  You don't mind, do  you?
She smiles.  He looks at her, expressionless.
Would you like a drink?  I was  just going to have one.
No, thanks.
She goes to the bar.
(smiles) That's right.  You're off the Jack  Daniels too, aren't you?
She is making herself a drink.  She takes the ice out and opens a drawer and gets an icepick.  It has a fat wooden She uses the icepick on the ice, her back to him.  He wat her.
I'd like to ask you a few more  questions.
I'd like to ask you some, too.
She turns to him, icepick in hand, smiles.
For my book.
She turns back to the ice, works on it with the pick.  Sh raises her arm, plunges it.  Raises it, plunges it.  He w her.
(wary) What kind of questions?
She puts the icepick down, pours herself a drink, turns t him.
How does it feel to kill someone?
He looks at her a long beat.
(finally) You tell me.
I don't know.  But you do.
Their eyes are on each other.
(finally) It was an accident.  They got in  the line of fire.
Four shootings in five years.  All  accidents.
(after a long beat) They were drug buys.  I was a vice  cop.
A long beat, as they look at each other.
Tell me about Professor Goldstein.
There's a name from the past.
You want a name from the present? How about Hazel Dobkins?
She looks at him a long beat, sips her drink, never takes eyes off him.
Noah was my counselor in my freshman  year. (she smiles) That's probably where I got the  idea for the icepick.  For my book. Funny how the subconscious works. (a beat) Hazel is my friend.
She wiped out her whole family.
Yes.  She's helped me understand  homicidal impulse.
Didn't you study it in school?
Only in theory. (she smiles) You know all about homicidal  impulse, don't you, shooter?  Not  in theory -- in practice.
He stares at her a long beat.
(quietly) What happened, Nick?  Did you get  sucked into it? Did you like it  too much?
(after a beat) No.
He stares at her, almost horrified.
(quietly) Tell me about the coke, Nick.  The  day you shot those two tourists -- how much coke did you do?
She steps closer to him.
Tell me, Nick.
She puts her hand softly on his cheek,  He grabs her hand roughly, holds it.
I didn't.
Yes, you did.  They never tested  you, did they?  But Internal Affairs  knew.
They are face to face.  He is still holding her roughly b hand.
Your wife knew, didn't she?  She  knew what was going on.  Nicky got  too close to the flame.  Nicky  liked it.
He twists her arm back behind her -- their bodies are pre against each other -- their eyes digging into each other.
(in a whisper) That's why she killed herself?

He is twisting her arm, staring at her, pulling her again him.  We hear the DOOR behind them.  A beat, and he lets go, turns away from her. Roxy stands there, staring at them.  Her hair is up.  She a black motorcycle jacket, a black T-shirt, and black jea and cowboy boots.
(brightly) Hiya, hon.  You two have met,  haven't you?
Roxy looks at Nick.  Catherine goes to her, kisses her br on the lips, stands there with her arm around her --both them looking at Nick. He walks by them, opens the door to go, his face a mask.
You're going to make a terrific  character, Nick.
He doesn't look at her; he's gone.
He comes in.  He looks like he's going to kill someone. RECEPTIONIST sits there.
She's on the phone -- she'll be  right with you, detective --He  sweeps by her into Beth's inner  office.  She hangs up when she  sees the look on his face.
Who has access to my file?
What are you talking about, Nick -- what's wrong with you?
Who's got access to my goddamn  file?
She gets up -- he goes closer to her; she backs away from
Nobody.
He goes closer to her; she backs away.
It's a confidential psychiatric  record, it'd be illegal --She backs  into a wall.  She looks very scared.   He comes very close to her -- puts  an arm behind her to the wall.
Don't, Beth.  Don't lie to me.
She says nothing, looks scared.
(suddenly) It's Internal Affairs, isn't it?
No, Nick, please --
(loud, hard) Who?
(blurts it) Nilsen.

He storms into the big room.  He sees MARTY NILSEN.  He i sitting behind his desk in his glass-enclosed office insi this big room.  About a dozen plainclothes policemen are the big room.  He goes by them into Nilsen's office.
He closes the door.  Nilsen sees the look on his face, ba his chair away towards the wall.
What do you want, Curran?
He goes to him, picks him up by his lapels, slams him aga the wall.
(out of control) You sold her the file, didn't you?
(scared) What are you talking about?
(out of control) What'd she pay you?
He slams him against the wall again.  The glass EXPLODES them -- a chair comes into the room.  Nick is frozen, hol Nilsen by the throat against the wall.
Let him go, Curran.  Nice and easy.
He looks back, sees two Internal Affairs men with their g drawn, pointed at him.  A beat, and he lets Nilsen go.  H turns calmly and starts to walk out.
You're on sick leave, Shooter.  As  of right now.  Pending the outcome  of a psychiatric evaluation.
He gets into his old Porsche.  He STARTS the car up.  Gus comes up to the window.  They look at each other a
What's goin' down, son?
Nothin' (a beat) I'll be okay, pop.
They look at each other a long beat.
No, sir.  You won't.  There's smoke  off yonder on the horizon.  They're  gonna want your badge.
(after a long beat) I got tired of being played with.
(after a beat) You sure got real conclusive ways  of demonstrating that.
They almost smile at each other, then --
(almost to himself) She knows where I live and breathe.   She's coming after me.
(after a long beat) What is it you got between you?
(after a beat; to  himself) I don't know.
Somethin', though.
A beat, and then Nick looks at him.
Yeah. (a beat) Somethin'.
He sits in front of the TV, watching a lame sitcom.  A bo of Jack Daniels is half-empty in front of him.  He is smo a cigarette.
(behind him) I still have my key.
He looks at her, looks away at the sitcom.
I don't want to see you, Beth.
He keeps watching the sitcom.  A long beat.
(suddenly angry) Damnit!  Don't shut me out!  You  owe me more than that?
He goes to the TV, shuts it off.
I don't owe you anything; you don't  owe me anything. (he looks at her) We went to bed -- what was it? -- ten or fifteen times? (he smiles) It wasn't memorable enough to carry  any obligations.
(after a long beat) Sometimes I really hate you.
(smiles) Yeah?  Well why don't you find  some friendly therapist and work  some of that hostility out. (a beat) But take my advice.  Put a little  more life into it than you usually  do.

A beat, and she suddenly hurls herself at him in absolute trying to claw at his face.  He grabs her, blocks her.  T look at each other a long beat and then he lets her go. The emotion of the moment is gone now -- they turn away f each other.
(finally) I'm sorry... I don't usually...  act like that.
Nick looks at her a beat.
How could you let him have my file,  Beth?
A long beat, then --

(not looking at him) He was going to recommend your  discharge a behavioral disability.   I made a deal with him.  He could  review the session notes himself.   It was the only way I could keep  you on the force.
She looks at him.  He looks away from her.
You did it for me.
Yes.  I care about you.  I did it  for you.
He turns away from her.
(quietly) Get out of here, Beth. (a beat) Please?
He goes to the Jack Daniel's, pours some more.  She looks him pour it and turns to go.
He is asleep on the couch -- the TV is on to a blank scre The Jack Daniel's is mostly gone.  The phone on the coffe table RINGS.  It RINGS again.  He wakes, picks it up, lis
Yeah. (a beat) Okay.
He hangs it up.  He sits there a long beat, staring.  He disturbed.

location: THE ALLEY BEHIND THE TEN-FOUR BAR

text: He walks down the alley.  There are lots of police cars,  flashing lights, uniformed men, coroner's men. As he walks down the alley, he sees Lt. Walker, Gus, and of the Internal Affairs men we saw earlier in Nilsen's of They are standing around a Lincoln Town Car. They look at him as he comes closer to them -- then move He can see into the car now.  Martin Nilsen lies against front seat.  He has been shot in the head.  Nick stares.
One shot.  Close range.  Probably  a .38 caliber revolver.
Nick stares at Nilsen's body.  They watch him.
Give me your gun, Nick.
A beat, and then Nick gives him his gun.  Walker smells i shakes his head, gives it to one of the Internal Affairs
(to Walker) You think I --
I don't son, but I got the minority  opinion.

He sits in the same room that Catherine sat in --surround four or five Internal Affairs men, Lt. Walker, Gus, and Captain Talcott.  Lt. Walker and Gus sor sit back -- I.A. is running the investigation.  The same stenographer -- the same plain young woman -- is sitting the room who was there with Catherine.
Okay.  I went after him.  I lost  my temper.
Do you have any evidence that he  showed your psychiatric file to  anyone?
(after a beat) No.
Beth Gardner comes into the room.  They look at her.
We'll speak to you afterwards, Dr. Gardner.
Nick gives her a look.
I'd like to sit-in if you don't  mind.
I'd really rather --
I don't see anything wrong with  Dr. Gardner sitting-in if Detective  Curran doesn't object.
Nick looks at her, shrugs.
Where were you tonight?
Home. Watching TV.
All night?
Yeah.
Were you drinking?
He looks at Beth.
Yeah, I was drinking.
When did you start drinking again?
(after a beat) A couple days ago.

I saw Detective Curran at his  apartment around ten o'clock.  He  was sober and lucid.  I asked him  in my capacity as his departmental  therapist about his altercation  with Lt. Nilsen.  He expressed  regret and displayed no hostility.
(to Beth) How long were you at his apartment?
About fifteen minutes.  I saw there  was no reason for my concern and  left.
She and Nick look at each other.  He looks away and light cigarette.
There's no smoking in this building.
(after a beat) What are you gonna do -- charge me  with smoking?
It is the exact line that Catherine used.  A long beat.
I'll ask you once, Nick -- for the  record did you kill him?
No.
They look at him a beat.
Come on -- I'm going to storm into  his office in front of everybody  in the afternoon and then that  night I'm going to kill him?  I'd  have to be really dumb to do that.
Going after him before gets you  off the hook for killing him that's  your alibi.
Like writing a book about killing  a guy gets you off the hook for  killing him.
(to Walker) I don't understand.  What are you  talking about?  What book?
(to Nick) Private joke.
I don't think it's funny.
(grins) Well, hell, son, it's got a certain  ring to it, I'll say that.
He is by the elevators with Gus and Lt. Andrews.  He spot Beth going for the stairway.
(to Lt. Andrews) I'll get my stuff tomorrow.
Beth.
She stops.  He catches up to her.  They walk down the fli together.  They speak quietly.
Thank you.
She looks at him, smiles.  They keep walking down the ste
It's the least I could do...   considering I got you into this  mess with those reports.
(smiles) No.  I mean it, thank you.
She looks at him, smiles.
How do you know Catherine Tramell  saw my reports?
She knows stuff about me that only  you know.
(after a beat) She must really be something. (she smiles) From a clinical point of view.
What was she like in school?
I hardly knew her.  She gave me  the creeps, though.  I don't know  why.
They get outside.  Beth kisses him quickly, softly on the
Get some rest.  Promise?
He nods.  She starts walking toward her car.
Beth.  I didn't mean what I said.   About --
(smiles) Yes you did.  I'm a big girl.  I  can handle it.
She goes to her car.

He is cleaning his desk out, putting things into a duffel Only Andrews is in the room.  We see Lt. Walker sitting i glass-enclosed office. He closes the duffel bag, looks at the place a long beat. Andrews is watching him.  He goes up to Andrews
(after a beat) Take care, you hear?
(after a beat) Did you find out about her parents?
You're on leave, man. (a beat) You're on psycho leave.  I'm talking  to a possible whacko here.
You know I'm whacko, Sam, what'd  you find?
A beat, and Andrews opens the file.

The boat blew.  There was a leak  in the gas line.  There were two  previous repairs.  There was a  five-mil policy on both of 'em.  A  real heavy investigation.  Zilch.   Goose-egg.  It was an accident.
(after a beat) Thanks.
He sees Lt. Walker looking at him.  He goes into Walker's office.
I.A.'s going to talk to you more  about Nilsen.  They're handling  the investigation, we're not.   Stay in touch with Dr. Gardner,  it'll help on the evaluation.
(after a beat) She killed him.
Beth?  Now you've got Beth killing  people?
Catherine Tramell.  It's part of  her game.
First you've got her buying your  file.  Now you've got her killing  Nilsen.  Forget her, willya?  Go  someplace.  Sit in the sun.  Get  away from this goddamn fog.  Get  her out of your system.
You don't but it, do you?  She  knew nobody would but it. (he smiles) She knew I'd say she did it.  And  she knew nobody would buy it.
Lt. Walker looks at him a long beat.
She's screwing with your head,  Nick.  Pretty soon you're gonna  look in the mirror and think you're  seeing her.

It is in the Marina District; on a street like Cervantes. He gets out of his old Porsche; he sees her black Ferrari She is sitting on the front stoop.  She wears an Indian j jeans and a T-shirt.  He goes up to her. She looks at him beat.
I heard about what happened.  What  good's a shooter without his gun?
She smiles.
(a beat) How exactly did you hear?
(after a beat) I have attorneys.  They have  friends.  I have friends.  Money  buys you a lot of attorneys and  friends.
(after a beat) I don't know about that I don't  have any money I don't have any  attorneys Gus is my only real  friend.
(smiles) I wasn't talking about real friends.   Why doesn't Gus like me.
(after a beat) I like you.
Do you?
(smiles) Yeah.  Would you like to come up  and have a drink?
She looks at him a beat.
I didn't think you'd ask me.
He looks at her a beat.
(smiles) I'm not that easy to figure.
They start walking inside.  She walks ahead of him.  He w her.  She turns suddenly.
You're not easy to figure.  I'm  just very good at figuring.
(after a beat) Don't get too cocky.
Why not?
You can make a mistake.
(smiles) Not me.
And she turns, heads inside; he follows her.
They walk in.  She looks at the bareness of the place.
You should put some warmth into  it.  You don't want it to reflect  on your personality.
She turns, smiles at him.  He looks at the bottle of Jack Daniel's; there's not much left.
Jack Daniel's okay?  It's gonna  have to be.
Fine.
Ice?
(smiles) Please.
There is a palpable tension between them. He takes the ice out, opens a drawer, takes out an icepic
Let me do that.  You like to watch  me doing it, don't you?
She smiles; a beat and he hands her the icepick.  She tak it, starts to us the icepick, her back to him.  He lights cigarette.
Can I have a cigarette, please?  I  told you you'd start smoking again.
He watches her working on the ice.
Light it for me, will you?
He does, steps to her.  She parts her lips -- he puts it her lip, watches it.  Their eyes are on each other.
Thank you.
She works on the ice again, opens the cabinets for glasse
What did you pay Nilsen?
(doesn't look at  him) Isn't he the policeman that you  shot, Shooter?
She makes the drinks.
What if I asked you not to call me  Shooter?
What if I call you Nicky?
(after a beat) My wife used to call me that.
(smiles) I know, Nicky, but I like it.
She hands him his drink, holds hers.
Cheers.  My friends call me  Catherine.
What did Bobby Vasquez used to  call you?
Bitch mostly, but he meant it  affectionately.  You don't have  any coke, do you?  I love coke and  Jack Daniel's.
(after a beat) There's Pepsi in the fridge.
(smiles) It's not the same thing, is it?
They look at each other a long beat, their eyes very invo
(quietly) Where's it going?  What do you  want from me?
Their faces are close together.
Say -- "What do you want from me,  Catherine?"
(after a beat,  quietly) What do you want from me, Catherine?
A beat, and she suddenly turns away.
(brightly) I brought you something.
She goes to her purse, takes a paperback book out of it. see it -- The First Time, by Catherine Smith.  He looks a
(smiles) Aren't you going to thank me?
What's it about?
A boy kills his parents.  They  have a plane.  He makes it look  like an accident.
He stares at her.  A long beat, then --
Why does he do it?
To see if he can get away with it.
They look at each other a beat.
When did you write it?
(after a beat) You mean did I write it before my  parents died?
Yes.
No.  I wrote it years afterwards.
He watches her; she has turned away from him -- and then turns back to him in a different mood.
(smiles) You're not going to stop following  me around now just because you're  on leave -- are you?
(after a beat) No.
Good.  I'd miss you. (a beat) You can get into trouble, though. You're not really a cop anymore.
I'll risk it.
Why take the risk?
To see if I can get away with it.
She looks at him; she smiles.
How's your new book?
I'm getting deeper and deeper into  my character.
They look at each other a long beat.
Thanks for the drink.
He nods, say nothing as she goes to the door --
I'm leaving the house around  midnight.  In case you're going to  follow me. (a beat) I'm going down to Johnny's club.
(after a beat) I'll meet you there.
She looks at him a long beat; and she's gone.
As she is going down the stairs, Gus Moran is coming up. He does a real double-take as he goes by her.
(smiles) Hi, Gus.
He looks at him a long beat, and he goes upstairs, into N apartment.
Nick stands at the window, watching her outside.  A long and he looks at Gus.
